TEXT.English: [TAB]Lead, symbol Pb (Latin plumbum, a lead weight), dense, bluish-gray metallic element that was one of the first known metals. The atomic number of lead is 82; the element is in group 14 (or IVa) of the periodic table. Lead is used in enormous quantities in storage batteries and in sheathing electric cables. Large quantities are used in industry for lining pipes, tanks, and X-ray apparatus. Because of its high density and nuclear properties, lead is used extensively as protective shielding for radioactive material. Among numerous alloys containing a high percentage of lead are solder, type metal, and various bearing metals. A considerable amount of lead is consumed in the form of its compounds, particularly in paints and pigments. Lead has been used by humans for at least 7000 years, because it is widespread, easy to extract and easy to work with. It is highly malleable and ductile as well as easy to melt. In the early bronze age lead was used with antimony and arsenic. Lead was mentioned in the Book of Exodus. Alchemists thought that lead was the oldest metal and associated it with the planet Saturn. Lead pipes that bear the insignia of Roman emperors are still in service and many Roman "pigs" (ingots) of lead figure in Derbyshire lead mining history and in the history of the industry in other English centres. Lead's symbol Pb is an abbreviation of its Latin name plumbum. The English word "plumbing" also derives from this Latin root. However, it is also toxic, and lead poisoning was recognized even by the ancients. Similarly, in the Twentieth Century, the use of lead in paint pigments was ended because of the danger of lead poisoning, especially to children. By the mid-1980s, a significant shift in lead end-use patterns had taken place. Much of this shift was a result of the U.S. lead consumers' compliance with environmental regulations that significantly reduced or eliminated the use of lead in nonbattery products, including gasoline, paints, solders, and water systems. Recently, lead use is being further curtailed by the RoHS directive.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Plomb, Pb de symbole (plumbum latin, un poids de plomb), l'élément métallique dense et gris-bleuâtre qui était l'un des premiers métaux connus. Le nombre atomique de plomb est 82 ; l'élément est dans le groupe 14 (ou IVa) de la table périodique. Le plomb est employé en énorme quantité dans des batteries de stockage et en engainant les câbles électriques. De grandes quantités sont employées dans l'industrie pour des pipes de doublure, des réservoirs, et l'appareillage de rayon X. En raison de ses propriétés à haute densité et nucléaires, le plomb est employé intensivement comme l'armature protectrice pour le matériel radioactif. Parmi de nombreux alliages contenant un pourcentage élevé de plomb soyez soudure, type métal, et divers métaux de roulement. Une quantité considérable de plomb est consommée sous forme de ses composés, en particulier en peintures et colorants. Le plomb a été employé par des humains pendant au moins 7000 années, parce qu'il est répandu, facile d'extraire et facile à travailler avec. Il est fortement malléable et malléable comme facile à fondre. Dans l'âge en bronze jeune le plomb a été employé avec de l'antimoine et l'arsenic. Le plomb a été mentionné dans le livre de l'exode. Les alchimistes ont pensé que menez était le métal le plus ancien et associé lui à la planète Saturne. Menez les pipes qui soutiennent les insignes des empereurs romains sont toujours en service et beaucoup de "porcs" romains (des lingots) de chiffre de plomb en plomb de Derbyshire extrayant l'histoire et dans l'histoire de l'industrie à d'autres centres anglais. Le Pb du symbole du plomb est une abréviation de son plumbum nommé latin. Le mot anglais "tuyauterie" dérive également de cette racine latine. Cependant, il est également toxique, et l'empoisonnement de plomb a été identifié même par les ancients. De même, au vingtième siècle, l'utilisation du plomb en colorants de peinture a été finie en raison du danger du plomb empoisonnant, particulièrement aux enfants. Par le milieu des années 80, une variation significative dans l'usage final de plomb a modelé avait eu lieu. Beaucoup de ce décalage était un résultat de la conformité des consommateurs de plomb des ETATS-UNIS aux règlements environnementaux qui ont réduit ou ont éliminé de manière significative l'utilisation du plomb dans des produits de nonbattery, y compris l'essence, des peintures, des soudures, et des systèmes de l'eau. Récemment, l'utilisation de plomb est encore raccourcie par la directive de RoHS.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Lead, symbol Pb (Latin plumbum, a lead weight), dense, bluish-gray metallic element that was one of the first known metals. The atomic number of lead is 82; the element is in group 14 (or IVa) of the periodic table. Lead is used in enormous quantities in storage batteries and in sheathing electric cables. Large quantities are used in industry for lining pipes, tanks, and X-ray apparatus. Because of its high density and nuclear properties, lead is used extensively as protective shielding for radioactive material. Among numerous alloys containing a high percentage of lead are solder, type metal, and various bearing metals. A considerable amount of lead is consumed in the form of its compounds, particularly in paints and pigments. Lead has been used by humans for at least 7000 years, because it is widespread, easy to extract and easy to work with. It is highly malleable and ductile as well as easy to melt. In the early bronze age lead was used with antimony and arsenic. Lead was mentioned in the Book of Exodus. Alchemists thought that lead was the oldest metal and associated it with the planet Saturn. Lead pipes that bear the insignia of Roman emperors are still in service and many Roman "pigs" (ingots) of lead figure in Derbyshire lead mining history and in the history of the industry in other English centres. Lead's symbol Pb is an abbreviation of its Latin name plumbum. The English word "plumbing" also derives from this Latin root. However, it is also toxic, and lead poisoning was recognized even by the ancients. Similarly, in the Twentieth Century, the use of lead in paint pigments was ended because of the danger of lead poisoning, especially to children. By the mid-1980s, a significant shift in lead end-use patterns had taken place. Much of this shift was a result of the U.S. lead consumers' compliance with environmental regulations that significantly reduced or eliminated the use of lead in nonbattery products, including gasoline, paints, solders, and water systems. Recently, lead use is being further curtailed by the RoHS directive.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Cavo, Pb di simbolo (plumbum latino, un peso del cavo), elemento metallico denso e grigio bluastro che era uno dei primi metalli conosciuti. Il numero atomico di cavo è 82; l'elemento è nei gruppi 14 (o IVa) della tabella periodica. Il cavo è usato in quantità enorme in pile secondarie e nell'inguainamento dei cavi elettrici. Le grandi quantità sono usate nell'industria per i tubi del rivestimento, i carri armati e l'apparecchiatura dei raggi X. A causa delle relative proprietà ad alta densità e nucleari, il cavo è usato estesamente come protezione protettiva per materiale radioattivo. Fra le leghe numerose che contengono un'alta percentuale di cavo sia saldatura, lega per caratteri e vari metalli del cuscinetto. Una quantità considerevole di cavo è consumata sotto forma d'i relativi residui, specialmente in vernici e pigmenti. Il cavo è stato usato dagli esseri umani per almeno 7000 anni, perché è diffuso, facile da estrarre e facile funzionare con. È altamente malleabile e duttile come pure facile fondersi. Nell'età bronze giovane il cavo è stato usato con antimonio ed arsenico. Il cavo è stato accennato nel libro del exodus. I alchemists hanno ritenuto che conduca fosse il più vecchio metallo ed associato esso con il pianeta Saturno. Conduca i tubi che sopportano i insignia degli imperatori romani sono ancora in servizio e molti "maiali" romani (lingotti) della figura del cavo in cavo del Derbyshire che estrae la storia e nella storia dell'industria in altri centri inglesi. Il Pb di simbolo del cavo è un'abbreviazione del relativo plumbum nome latino. La parola inglese "impianto idraulico" inoltre deriva da questa radice latina. Tuttavia, è inoltre tossica e l'avvelenamento del cavo è stato riconosciuto anche dai ancients. Similmente, nel ventesimo secolo, l'uso di cavo in pigmenti della vernice è stato concluso a causa del pericolo di cavo che avvelena, particolarmente ai bambini. Entro i mid-1980s, una variazione significativa nell'uso finale del cavo ha modellato aveva avvenuto. Molto di questo spostamento era un risultato della conformità degli STATI UNITI dei consumatori del cavo alle regolazioni ambientali che significativamente hanno ridotto o eliminato l'uso di cavo nei prodotti di nonbattery, compreso benzina, in vernici, in saldature e nei sistemi dell'acqua. Recentemente, l'uso del cavo più ulteriormente sta accorciando dall'indirizzamento di RoHS.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Plomo, Pb del símbolo (plumbum latino, un peso del plomo), el elemento metálico denso, gris azulado que era uno de los primeros metales sabidos. El número atómico del plomo es 82; el elemento está en el grupo 14 (o IVa) de la tabla periódica. El plomo se utiliza en cantidades enormes en baterías de almacenaje y en el forro de los cables eléctricos. Las cantidades grandes se utilizan en la industria para las pipas de la guarnición, los tanques, y el aparato de la radiografía. Debido a sus características de alta densidad y nucleares, el plomo se utiliza extensivamente como blindar protector para el material radiactivo. Entre las aleaciones numerosas que contienen un alto porcentaje del plomo sea soldadura, tipo metal, y varios metales del cojinete. Una cantidad considerable de plomo se consume en la forma de sus compuestos, particularmente en pinturas y pigmentos. El plomo ha sido utilizado por los seres humanos por por lo menos 7000 años, porque es extenso, fácil extraer y fácil trabajar con. Es altamente maleable y dúctil tan bien como fácil derretir. En edad de bronce temprana el plomo fue utilizado con antimonio y arsénico. El plomo fue mencionado en el libro del éxodo. Los alquimistas pensaron que conduzca era el metal más viejo y asociado le al planeta Saturno. Conduzca las pipas que llevan las insignias de los emperadores romanos todavía están en servicio y muchos "cerdos romanos" (los lingotes) de la figura del plomo en el plomo de Derbyshire que mina historia y en la historia de la industria en otros centros ingleses. El Pb del símbolo del plomo es una abreviatura de su plumbum conocido latino. La palabra inglesa "plomería" también deriva de esta raíz latina. Sin embargo, es también tóxica, y el envenenamiento del plomo fue reconocido incluso por los ancients. Semejantemente, en el vigésimo siglo, el uso del plomo en pigmentos de la pintura fue terminado debido a el peligro del plomo que envenenaba, especialmente a los niños. Por los a mediados de los años ochenta, una cambio significativa en uso final del plomo modeló había ocurrido. Mucha de esta cambio era un resultado de la conformidad de ESTADOS UNIDOS de los consumidores del plomo con las regulaciones ambientales que redujeron o eliminaron perceptiblemente el uso del plomo en productos del nonbattery, incluyendo la gasolina, pinturas, soldaduras, y sistemas del agua. Recientemente, el uso del plomo está siendo acortado más a fondo por el directorio de RoHS.
